Pull apart (strike slip) basin developed on margin of continental crust that is obliquely overriding subducting oceanic plate.
Pull apart (strike slip) basin developed on oceanic arc that is obliquely overriding another subducting oceanic plate.
Structural basin developed on top of accretionary prism in front of oceanic arc developed on leading edge of continental plate that is overriding subducting oceanic plate .
Structural basin developed on top of accretionary prism in front of oceanic arc developed on leading edge of oceanic plate that is overriding subducting oceanic plate .
Fore-arc with basin carried on thrust sheet at continental margin.
Fore-arc with basin carried on thrust sheet in front of oceanic arc.
Basin developed immediately in front of advancing thrust or transgressional strike slip belt by loading/depression of (continental) crust by overriding crustal material (e.g. thrust sheets).
A depression entirely within continental crust caused by thermal subsidence following strike-slip pull apart within the continental crust.
A depression entirely within continental crust caused by thermal subsidence and/or sediment loading in a region of crustal weakness.
Pull apart (strike-slip) basin formed at extensional (non-restraining) offset in strike slip fault entirely within continental crust.
Pull apart (strike slip) basin developed within mountainous collision zone where continental crust is obliquely colliding with another continental plate.
Extensional basin formed by crustal delamination and/or crustal relaxation and thermal subsidence following collision between two continental plates.
Shallow to deep marine sediments deposited on trailing continental margin, across transition from extended continental to newer oceanic crust.
Redeposition of passive margin basin sediments on margins of uplift caused by later reverse movement on one or more continental margin extension faults.
Basin developed on one or both sides of mountainous collision massif developed in continent-continent collision zone.
Local topographic basin typically developed on top of active thrust and fold belt.
Basin localized by thermal subsidence of failed or inactive continental rift.
Redeposition of post-rift sag deposits on margins of uplift caused by later reverse motion on one or more rift-bounding extension faults.
Extensional basin occurring behind arc developed on continental margin above subducting oceanic slab.
Redeposition of retro-arc sediments adjacent to uplift caused by reverse motion on extensional basin occurring behind arc developed on continental margin above subducting oceanic slab.
Extensional basin occurring behind volcanic arc developed on overriding oceanic crust above subducting oceanic slab.
Basin developed behind volcanic arc superimposed on continental crust that is being thrust over itself, loading and depressing the adjacent continental crust.
Basin developed behind volcanic arc superimposed on oceanic crust that is being thrust over itself, loading and depressing the adjacent oceanic crust.
Later thermal subsidence of extensional basin occurring behind arc developed on continental margin above subducting oceanic slab.
Retro-arc Post-extensional Sag (Ocean - Continent) with Inversion
Redeposition of retro-arc post-extensional sediments adjacent to uplift caused by reverse motion on earlier extension faults near ocean-continent margin.
Later thermal subsidence of extensional basin occurring behind volcanic arc developed on overriding oceanic crust above subducting oceanic slab.
Typically a somewhat linear feature where continental crust has been pulled apart (extended).
Basin developed on extended top of mountainous collision massif developed in continent-continent collision zone.
Mechanical and thermal subsidence of (narrow) ocean basin trapped between two convergent continental masses.
Pull apart (strike-slip) basin formed at extensional (non-restraining) offset in strike slip fault system at margin between continental and oceanic crustal blocks.

Often used while drilling oil and natural gas wells. Drilling fluids is used to carry cuttings out of the hole.
Natural gas consisting of methane and possibly other gaseous hydrocarbons.
Many types of solid material are used to plug a leak from the uncased wellbore into a porous interval. The purpose is usually to restore circulation of the drilling fluid.
Drilling mud or slurry found in a wellbore to manage pressures in the wellbore
A general type without identifying if it came from the formation or was used in the operation. Oil in a blowout may also contain unreported gas
Any non-hydrocarbon gas, e.g. CO2, hydrogen, including H2S
Any solid material used to support fractures in the formation.
Formation sand may be dislodged in the drilling process or by the formation fluid entering the wellbore.
Tools that include logging tools, drill pipe etc.
Any water in the liquid phase. Water may be present in the formation and/or used in the operation. The source and kind of water may be difficult to determine or the details may simply be unreported.

Long radius buildups are deviated mostly in open holes, with a rate from 1 to 6 degrees for every 100 feet of drilling.  The horizontal section may be long, up to 5000 feet or more. Build rates of 2 to 6°/100 ft result in a radius of 3,000 to 1,000 ft.

This method is used when vertical access is difficult, such as in marine drilling or in land operations where surface access may be challenging or restricted.  They typically have larger hole sizes and can be created with more powerful equipment.
Medium build up radius may range from 6 to 35 degrees for every 100 feet of buildup. Build rates of 6 to 35°/100 ft, radii of 1,000 to 160 ft, and lateral sections of up to 8,000 ft.
The buildup section may be 200 to 700 or more feet, with a horizontal section up to 3500 feet.  Normally used for fractured zones.

A short buildup radius has about 60 feet (20 meters) of buildup desction, and between 100 and 800 feet of horizontal section. Build rates of 5 to 10°/3 ft (1.5 to 3°/ft), which equates to radii of 40 to 20 ft.
Typically, these have smaller diameters and are drilled with less powerful equipment, and they may have a higher failure rate. Commonly used for re-entry of an existing well.
An Ultra short buildup has a very small buildup radius. Radius of 20 ft or less.

This product is intended for use when special properties are not required. It is available only in ordinary (O) grade. Class A cement is similar to ASTM C 150, Type I with regard to both chemistry and fineness.

This product is intended for use when conditions require moderate or high sulfate-resistance. Class B cement is similar to Class A cement except that it is available in both moderate (MSR) and high sulfate-resistant (HSR) grades. The MSR grade is similar to ASTM C 150, Type II with regard to both chemistry and fineness. The HSR grade is similar to ASTM C 150 Type V with regard to both chemistry and fineness.

This product is intended for use when conditions require high early strength; it is typically the most finely ground of all API classes of well cement. It is available in ordinary (O), moderate sulfate-resistant (MSR), and high sulfate-resistant (HSR) grades. Class C (O) cement is similar to ASTM C 150, Type III.
This product is intended for use under conditions of moderately high temperatures. Specifications for Class D cement cover moderate sulfate-resistant (MSR) and high sulfate-resistant (HSR) grades.
This product is similar to Class D cement. It is intended for use under conditions of high temperature.
This product is similar to Class D cement. It is intended for use under conditions of extremely high temperatures.

No additions other than calcium sulfate or water, or both, shall be interground or blended with the clinker during manufacture of Class G well cement. This product is intended for use as a basic well cement. Available in MSR and HSR grades.

No additions other than calcium sulfate or water, or both, shall be interground or blended with the clinker during manufacture of Class H well cement. This product is intended for use as a basic well cement. Available in MSR and HSR grades.
Six digit combination of numbers and letters defined by its mix of red, green and blue.
Used for printing, data visualization, etc.
Used for printing, data visualization, etc.
A casing completion refers to a configuration in which tubulars are istalled across a formation interval.  These tublars may be cemented or uncemented or installed with open hole packers

A liner is a casing string that is set across the producing interval but does not return to surface.  Rather it is hung inside the inner diameter of a previous casing via a liner hanger and packer isolation
Monobore refers to a configuration in which tubulars of the same or similar size ID and properties are installed from TD to surface.
Casing may be run as the hole is drilled. When the formation is penetrated and oil and gas began to flow, drilling is ceased and the well is produced as an open hole completion
A casing string that is installed and landed at the top of a liner completion to provide a similar dimension coduit with similar properties or greater of the liner to surface.
Lossy data compression (a general category of methods) eliminates data perceived to be less important or relevant in favor of reducing file size.  Lossy compressions cannot be reversed.
A wavelet transform where the discrete-time (sampled) signal is passed through more filters than the discrete wavelet transform (DWT).

LZ77 and LZ78 are the two lossless data compression algorithms published in papers by Abraham Lempel and Jacob Ziv in 1977[1] and 1978...They are both theoretically dictionary coders.
ARC is a lossless data compression and archival format. The file format and the program were both called ARC.

LPC is a method used mostly in audio signal processing and speech processing for representing the spectral envelope of a digital signal of speech in compressed form, using the information of a linear predictive model.
A lossy data compression framework based on an approximate two-dimensional (2D) pattern matching (2D-PMC) extension of the Lempel-Ziv (1977, 1978) lossless scheme.
A data differencing algorithm takes as input source data and target data, and produces difference data such that given the source data and the difference data, one can reconstruct the target data
A simple form of data compression in which the most common pair of consecutive bytes of data is replaced with a byte that does not occur within that data.
A dictionary coder, LZ77 maintains a sliding window during compression.

SBC is any form of transform coding that breaks a signal into a number of different frequency bands, typically by using a fast Fourier transform, and encodes each one independently. This decomposition is often the first step in data compression for audio and video signals.
BWT rearranges a character string into runs of similar characters. The process is reversible.
Lossless data compression algorithms use statistical data redundancy to represent data without losing any information, so that the process is reversible.

Conceptually, LZ78 decompression could allow random access to the input if the entire dictionary were known in advance. However, in practice the dictionary is created during encoding and decoding by creating a new phrase whenever a token is output

DCT expresses a finite sequence of data points in terms of a sum of cosine functions oscillating at different frequencies. The DCT, first proposed by Nasir Ahmed in 1972, is a widely used transformation technique in signal processing and data compression

The information is generally accessible to anyone.
Access may be limited by other criteria such as the record medium, storage location or retrieval cost.
The information must not be accessed without explicit approval
The information must not be accessed outside the organization or business unit without explicit approval.
Approval may be by contract, management declaration, data governance, etc.
The information must not be accessed beyond the business unit or system without explicit approval.
Approval may be by contract, management declaration, data governance, etc.
A confidential status is not applied to the information item.
The information item is declared to be unclassified or a classification status has been revoked.
The information might be confidential but the status is unknown.
The status might be unknown because of an incomplete record, or inadequate access to the record.
A requirement, specified in a data sale or data sharing agreement, or a joint venture agreement, to hold confidential all data obtained pursuant to the agreement.
A specified duty to secure the data against unauthorized or unlawful access.
A duty, specified in a JOA or other agreement, to share with all parties the data obtained during the life the agreement.
A requirement to destroy all data, obtained through an agreement for data sharing or data subscription, after a specified period of time or other conditions.
As set out in an agreement, a requirement to spud or complete a well or wells before a specified date, in specified locations or according to other conditions in the agreement.
A limitation on the quantity of product exported to a specific country or countries by a Government.
Obligations for financial payments and accounting are specified in a Joint Operating Agreement, Lease, Purchase and Sale Agreement or other contract.
A requirement that data shared or delivered according to the agreement is used only for specified purposes.
A requirement to give advance notice to the lessor (permitter) or partners whereby the lessee (permittee) indicates the intention to terminate all or part of the lease.
A restriction on the use of certain products derived from data obtained through purchase or subscription from a third party.

An obligation in some leases that requires the holder of the mineral rights, by virtue of the terms of lease, to drill or take some other action on lands that offset [are adjacent to] acreage found to be productive. The lessor usually issues this obligation.

[A requirement to issue advance notice] of a proposed operation by a party in writing (usually the Operator) pursuant to an operating agreement to participate or not in the joint operation. The notice has a date in which responses must be received.
[Period payments, usually] including royalties, dues, fees, rates or charges other than money... but does not include money payable as the whole or part of a purchase price.
A requirement to submit interim, periodic or final reports to other parties in an agreement.
A requirement to submit data to another party to the agreement. The agreement may define the data types, formats, quality, timing of delivery, etc.
A requirement to return all data, obtained through an agreement for data sharing or data subscription, after a specified period of time or other conditions.

An exchange of pipeline capacity or pipeline transporting services for money. The transporter will typically charge a tariff.

This coring system for unconsolidated sediments has a special device to close the barrel before the assembly is lifted off the bottom of the hole.
A heavily weighted core tube is dropped into the seabed; a piston inside the tube creates a vacuum that draws the unconsolidated sediment upward into the tube.
This is used for offshore geotechnical reasons, e.g. rig stability or rig leg penetration.
The coring system holds the core at the reservoir pressure, thus retaining all fluids in the core.
This is the best method for oil saturation studies.
The core barrel has an inner rubber sleeve to aid in recovering unconsolidated or highly fractured rock.
The core barrel has a sponge liner that traps the reservoir oil while allowing gas and water to escape.
This is used for some oil saturation studies.
Standard or routine cylindrical continuous core, typically cut in 2.375-5.5 inch diameters, and in 6 or 9 metre core barrel lengths.
Shallow sediment cores typically collected for geo-technical reasons, for example, rig stability or rig leg penetration.

The curve is an almost straight line on a semi-log graph. The decline rate is constant over time. Used for a well producing at constrant bottom hole pressure.
The curve is concave upwards on a semi-log plot. A special form of hyperbolic decline.
The curve is concave upwards on a semi-log plot. The decline rate changes over time.
A vertical cylinder with stacked plates that filter the fluid. Typically used for production fluid not drilling fluid.
The fluid is held in a tank to allow the sand-sized particles to settle by gravity.

A cone shaped device that creates a radial vortex to remove solid particles by centrifugal force. A hydrocyclone in a desander removes a high proportion of sand particles (diameter 0.074 mm and larger.)
A cylindrical device that rotates on a vertical axis to expel solids from a liquid by centrifugal force.
desander and desilters do not have centrifuges
A vertical cylinder with stacked plates that filter the fluid. Typically used for production fluid not drilling fluid.

A cone shaped device that creates a radial vortex to remove solid particles by centrifugal force. A hydrocyclone in a desilter removes a high proportion of fine particles that have escaped the desander process.
A cylindrical device that rotates on a vertical axis to expel solids from a liquid by centrifugal force.
Not a piece of equipment to remove silt
Fines take too long to settle.
A device to detect sand in production fluid and alert to the need for a desander.
Not a device to remove sand or silt
Rotation of the drill string causes magnetisation along the drill string axis. This alters the horizontal component of the Earth’s magnetic field and affects the magnetic azimuth sensor.
Local distortion of the Earth's magnetic field from magnetism in the rocks or tools.
For some older wells, the available directional survey is a paper report of computed values for each depth station. Errors may occur in digitizing the report.
A gyroscope is a very sensitive device, affected by temperature, mass imbalance, vibration, shock, time-related drift, random bias, etc.

Declination is the horizontal angle between the geographic North Pole and magnetic north. Declination depends on geographic location of the well and varies with time. An incorrect declination value is a significant source of error.
Local distortion of the Earth's magnetic field from magnetism in the rocks, tools and drill string.
Depths determined by the length of the drill string are subject to error because of stretch and compression. Depth errors for a wireline-conveyed survey tool are less significant.
The survey tool may not be precisely parallel to the wellbore centerline. There are several causes including a bent assembly or sag.

The survey tool is contained within a string assembly that must be flexible to follow bends in the wellbore. The flexibility means that the assembly is not always parallel to the wellbore centerline. This affects the survey measurements, especially for inclination.

Only Measured Depth and Azimuth are provided for each survey station, Inclination values are not available, probably because of tool failure.  This data is insufficient to calculate an accurate well path.
Measured Depth, Inclination and Azimuth values are all three provided for each survey station.  This is the most common situation.

Only Measured Depth and Inclination are provided for each survey station. Azimuth values are not available. This survey is insufficient to calculate an accurate well path but can be used to calculate the maximum possible deflection of the bottom of the survey interval if all the inclinations are assumed to be in the same direction.
Measured Depth and calculated True Vertical Depth, X and Y Offsets are provided for each survey station, but Inclination and Azimuth values are not available.

Utilizes the angles at the top and bottom of the course length and from these generates a curve on the assumption that the measured angles change smoothly from top to bottom of the measured course as though under the influence of a constant force of acceleration. The results obtained are the same as the "Balanced Tangential" "Trapezoidal" and "Vector Averaging" Methods.

Uses the average of the inclinations and azimuths measured at the upper and lower survey stations. The average of the two sets of angles is assumed to be the inclination and the azimuth over the incremental measured depth. The wellbore path is then calculated using simple trigonometric functions.

Uses the inclination and direction angles at the top and bottom of the course length in a manner so as to tangentially balance the two sets of measured angles over the course length. Results obtained are the same as the "Acceleration" "Trapezoidal" and "Vector Averaging" Methods.  The balanced tangential method is rarely used but is the basis for the minimum curvature method.

Uses both sets of measured angles associated with each course length to recreate the wellbore path as a sequence of circular arcs constrained by the measured angles to pass through the end points with inclination and direction angles as measured.

The constant-curvature method developed is based on drilling tendencies of the bottom hole assembly and the technical advancement in directional drilling. It yields a trajectory with less maximum dogleg severity, less drag, and less torque in the drill string compared to the conventional radius-of-curvature and constant-turn-rate methods. The equations for the constant-curvature method can easily be used during directional drilling and are especially useful for horizontal drilling where a constant build rate is desired.

A combination of the Tangential and Balanced Tangential Methods, so as to treat that portion of the measured course length defined by the length of the measuring tool in a straight line (tangentially) and the remainder of the measured course in a Balanced Tangential manner (trapezoidially). The name, Mercury Method, originated from the common use of this method at the Atomic Energy Commission's test site, Mercury, Nevada.  As can be seen from the expression in the definition, the method is basically the Balanced Tangential Method with corrections made for the rigid length of the survey instrument.  It should be pointed out that other methods can be utilized to replace the Balanced Tangential portion of this method and not create any error involved in the system, and may, in fact, improve on the accuracy of the computations.   Also, refer to "Compensated Acceleration Method" and "Combined Method". (API Bulletin D20, pages 6 and 9)

Uses the sets of angles measured at the top and bottom of the course length to establish coordinate velocities through which a space curve (which represents the calculated path of the wellbore) passes in a manner that minimizes its total curvature.  This model takes the space vectors defined by inclination and direction measurements and smooths them onto the wellbore curve (Figure 13). This method is really a modification of the balanced tangential method. Instead of approximating the wellbore path with two straight lines, the minimum curvature replaces these lines with a circular arc. This arc is calculated by using a dogleg scale factor based on the amount of angular change over the course length.
A method in math modeling considering the wellbore as a curve: the projections into three vertical planes are quadratic functions.

Uses the inclination and azimuth measured at the upper and lower ends of the course length to generate a circular arc when viewed in both the vertical and horizontal planes. This method assumes that the well path lies on a cylinder whose axis is vertical, and has a radius equal to the radius of curvature in the horizontal plane. It determines the length of the arc between the upper and lower ends of the course length in the horizontal plane. The cylinder can then be “unwrapped” to calculate the length of the circular arc along the cylinder surface. Consequently the incremental TVD is unaffected by changes in azimuth.
Has been used with two different meanings: 1) the "Trapezoidal Method" and 2)  the "Average Angle Method".

Uses as many measured angle values as are available (a minimum of three sets) to recreate the wellbore path through Simpson's rule for numeric integration which approximates by passing a parabola through three points.

Uses the inclination and azimuth at the lower end of the course length to calculate a straight line that represents the well bore, and passes through the lower end of the course length. The wellbore is assumed to be a straight line throughout the course length. This method is the most inaccurate of the methods discussed and should not be used in the determination of survey results unless the course lengths are not longer than the length of the survey tool. Some legacy surveys have been computed with this method.
The spiral distance between stations is computed in ten equal intervals. For example, a 200 foot ten-chord spiral would be computed at a 20 foot interval.
For some surveys of old wells, the method is unknown.

Uses inclination and direction measurements at both ends of the measured course to establish vector space directions. It is then assumed that each of these two vectors is projected for one-half the course length in creating the wellbore path.  Each "half-course length" segment can be treated tangentially. Results obtained are essentially the same as the "Acceleration", "Balanced Tangential" and "Trapezoidal" Methods.

Uses the inclination and azimuth measured at the upper and lower ends of the course length to generate a circular arc when viewed in both the vertical and horizontal planes. This method assumes that the well path lies on a cylinder whose axis is vertical, and has a radius equal to the radius of curvature in the horizontal plane. It determines the length of the arc between the upper and lower ends of the course length in the horizontal plane. The cylinder can then be “unwrapped” to calculate the length of the circular arc along the cylinder surface. Consequently the incremental TVD is unaffected by changes in azimuth.

Uses the inclination and azimuth measured at the upper and lower ends of the course length to generate a circular arc when viewed in both the vertical and horizontal planes. This method assumes that the well path lies on a cylinder whose axis is vertical, and has a radius equal to the radius of curvature in the horizontal plane. It determines the length of the arc between the upper and lower ends of the course length in the horizontal plane. The cylinder can then be “unwrapped” to calculate the length of the circular arc along the cylinder surface. Consequently the incremental TVD is unaffected by changes in azimuth.
Prior Azimuth values have been corrected from Grid north reference to Magnetic north
Prior Azimuth values have been corrected from Grid north reference to True north
Prior Azimuth values have been corrected from Magnetic north reference to Grid north
Prior Azimuth values have been corrected from Magnetic north reference to True north
Prior Azimuth values have been corrected from True north reference to Grid north
Prior Azimuth values have been corrected from True north reference to Magnetic north
Direct measured end point. This survey station is the last station obtained by direct measurement.

This survey station was extrapolated beyond the measured data by using a) straight-line method (constant direction and inclination), or b) estimated rate of change in hole direction/inclination. These are final report terminology.
This virtual survey station was interpolated between two existing actual and/or virtual survey stations.
This survey station was obtained by direct measurement (AKA Normal.)
A Tie Point in the wellbore shared as the means to merge two surveys.
This point can be further classified as real (apparently valid), fake (unreliable, generally calculated with trig), missing, or erroneous (typos, wrong calc method used in generating tie, etc.)
Projected End Point, This survey station was projected to the wellbore end depth following the existing directional survey path.
A Tie Point at or near the surface, shared as the means to merge two surveys.
This point can be further classified as real (apparently valid), fake (unreliable, generally calculated with trig), missing, or erroneous (typos, wrong calc method used in generating tie, etc.)
The point shared as the means to merge two surveys.

This point has a known position and therefore allows the connecting survey to be correctly referenced in space. It can be a Surface Tie or a Mid Course Tie. It can be further classified as real (apparently valid), fake (unreliable, generally calculated with trig), missing, or erroneous (typos, wrong calc method used in generating tie, etc.)
Virtual survey stations are estimated between measured stations.
Two processing methods have been applied to the survey.
Only measurement stations are used for survey calculations.
A subjective assessment that the quality is entirely acceptable.
A subjective assessment that the quality is probably acceptable for a specific purpose.
A subjective assessment that the quality is generally acceptable or suitable for a specific purpose.
A subjective assessment that the quality is unreliable but may have some limited value for a specific purpose.
Even a poor data set may have something that can be extracted for a purpose.
A subjective assessment that the quality is completely unreliable.
Magnetic deflection from hot spots in the equipment or from close proximity to magnetic elements in the drill string.
Cross-axial magnetic interference can cause significant survey errors, especially when the well being surveyed is in an east/west direction or approximately horizontal.
The inability of the tool to freefall in an inclined wellbore.
Freefall decreases substantially at approximately 60°. Consequently, gyro performance degrades at 60°, and most gyros cannot be used to survey at greater than 70°.
The instrument must be calibrated properly.
The survey instrument performance depends on the package design elements, calibration performance, and quality control during operation.
System performance will functionally depend on the borehole inclination, azimuth, geomagnetic-field vector, and geographical position.
Corruption of the measured geomagnetic field by an external source.

Drill string (axial) interference is probably the most common and frequent cause of errors in hole direction. Magnetic interference is the corruption of the geomagnetic field by a field from an external source. This can cause serious errors in measuring hole direction (azimuth). Potential sources of magnetic interference are: drill strings, adjacent wells, casing shoes, magnetic formations, hot spots in non-magnetic drill collars.
Depth errors are related to the physical measurement of drill pipes, the differential effects of drill string compression and stretch, and wireline stretch.

Wireline survey tools generally have smaller depth errors than drill string-conveyed tools, provided adequate quality-control measures have been taken. Errors on the order of 1/1,000 for gyroscopic tools and 2/1,000 for drill string tools are commonly quoted. However, this may not apply to horizontal-well situations.
Misalignment of the survey instrument with the wellbore.
Misalignment results in errors in wellbore-axis direction and inclination. The misalignment can be sensor to instrument, instrument to drill string, and/or drill string to wellbore.
Regardless of the system or sensor type, the quality of the survey is controlled by the surveyor.
The inherent design limitation on performance of a survey tool relative to latitude.

Because of the dependency on sensing Earth’s spin rate, the performance of gyro compassing tools is inversely proportional to the cosine of the latitude of wellbore location. The sensor system performance generally degrades as the inclination increases, especially in an east/west direction at higher latitudes. For magnetic tools, high latitudes result in weaker horizontal components of Earth’s field. For two-axis gyro tools, the approach to east/west at high inclinations places the sensor axes increasingly parallel to Earth’s spin. With magnetic tools, errors increase at high east/west inclinations because of the progressive difficulty in compensating for the effect of drill string magnetism.
A processing uncertainty may arise if the survey duration was long enough to be affected by drift in a processing parameter.

The time component may be significant for gyro systems, particularly in horizontal wells and possibly in east/west orientation. The survey duration inevitably extends beyond the average survey-duration period. Long survey duration means larger drift uncertainty and more exposure to the wellbore environment, which may potentially reduce the accuracy of directional data.
Measurements are taken at a very short depth interval during a run.
This allows for a detailed analysis of the wellbore trajectory. This value is suitable for MWD (measure while drilling) and wireline devices that transmit the data to the surface in real time.
The survey tool is capable of measurements at multiple depth stations a run.

This value is suitable for a device that obtains data at more than one specific pre-determined depth in a run. Early devices used a mechanical or photographic recording method. Digital devices are now available.
The survey tool is capable of measurements at only one depth station in a run.
Early devices used a mechanical or photographic recording method. Digital devices are now available.
The survey report combines data from two or more runs during the drilling of the wellbore, which may or may not use different instruments and which may or may not have overlapping depth intervals.
A report that includes surveys taken from one or more instruments belonging to the same or different service provider at different phases of the well life cycle.  API RP 78 draft v.9, p.9 definition.
RP78 draft r.9, Sec. 2.7. API-RP78 Directional Survey Records - www.iscwsa.net/files/601/. See also BSEE regulation.

A composite directional survey for a given wellbore from the bottom of the conductor casing to total depth with all depths, azimuths and calculated values corrected to consistent references.  Only one Definitive Survey should be defined for a given wellbore.  If new or improved (e.g. improved azimuth reference models, more advanced survey correction, additional data, etc.) borehole trajectory data becomes available, the corrected directional survey becomes the new "Definitive Survey" and the prior version reference changed to "Composite".
The survey is from a single run of the survey instrument.
The MWD device contains 3 oriented accelerometers and related sensors. Accelerometer and gyroscope use different physical principles.

A bottle of acid is lowered in the wellbore after the drill string is removed and left at a specified depth long enough for the acid to etch a line on the glass or copper bottle. The angle between the etch line and the axis of the bottle shows the inclination.
Gyroscopic systems are of several kinds: free gyro, rate gyro, inertial navigation.

Magnetic sensors must be run within a nonmagnetic environment (uncased hole, nonmagnetic drill collar or wireline] and there must not be any magnetic interference from adjacent wells. Magnetic sensors can be classified into two categories: mechanical compass or electronic compass.
This includes the Totco trade name
A statement reduced to writing and sworn or affirmed before someone who is authorized to administer an oath.
A document outlining the transfer of interest between various parties.
Proposed expenses for a particular project.

A completion report is written at the conclusion of specified operations in constructing a well. Regulatory and regional differences impact the details included, but often describe the lithology of the well, the steps taken to construct a wellbore, the results of various analysis and the outcome of the operation.
High resolution photographs are used as pictorial evidence of the rock structure in a core section.
Communications between two parties, emails, written documents
Typically logs from tapes, job runs, and other necessary printouts

Drilling reports are created by field operatives while a well is being drilled. They usually contain details about the equipment in use, the crew on duty, the lithology encountered, and materials used.
A document that lays out the plans for emergency response to an physical or environmental incident.  Usually lays out communications, activities, notifications and lines of authority.

Equipment specifications are written documents or manuals that describe of production capacity, mechanical tolerances, sizes, power requirement, fabrication methods and other details of the equipment.
Field notes are usually organized by time and may be taken during any field operations, and often provide informal descriptions about activities, materials and events.
Report of financial activities of particular projects, entities, or businesses

A legal term for any formally executed written document that...expresses a legally enforceable act, process, or contractual duty, obligation, or right...Examples include deed, lease, contract, legislative act.
A request for payment for a product or service.
Legislation, often called Acts, are passed by governments to describe what must or must not be done.

A barren landscape of very little precipitation and vegetation.

There are several ways to classify deserts but generally it is based on precipitation, humidity and temperature. Some deserts have sand dunes, others are mostly broken rock or bedrock. Salt pans, mud flats or temporary lakes may occur. Deserts are often windy. An aquifer may bring water to the surface as an oasis. Deserts occur in hot, temperate and polar climates.
The water flows downhill and may merge with streams before reaching a lake or sea.
A land area dominated by trees.
Forests are classified in many ways, including tree species, tree density, ecological function, land use and climate type.
Grasslands share the common climactic characteristic of semi-aridity. Trees are sparse or nonexistent, but flowers may be interspersed with the grasses.
A basin of water surrounded by land.

A lake is an area filled with water, localized in a basin, surrounded by land, apart from any river or other outlet that serves to feed or drain the lake.  Most lakes are fed and drained by rivers and streams.
A wetland dominated by herbaceous plants.
Marshes usually occur as a transition between aquatic and terrestrial systems. Trees and other woody plants are rare.
A marine area beyond the influence of the shore.
At sea with some distance from the shore

An area where a thick subsurface layer of soil and other materials remain frozen all year, usually in polar regions.

Transition zones are geographical areas of overlap with a gradient of change between land and wet (usually marine) zones.  These may be tidal in nature.
A region where tree growth is hindered by cold climate.
Tundra's occurs in polar and alpine regions. Vegetation is dominantly shrubs, sedges, grasses and lichens. The ground may contain permafrost.

The Carter coordinate system is a land grid, based on latitude and longitude, used to locate oil and gas well data in Kentucky. The system was developed by the Carter Oil Company to mimic the township and range location system in areas that had not been surveyed. The State is divided into a regular grid with each cell (or "quad") being five minutes of latitude by five minutes of longitude. These quads are assigned letters (equivalent of the township) beginning with "A" in the south and increasing through "Z" and "AA" to "GG" northward. The quads are assigned numbers (equivalent of the range) beginning with zero (0) in the west and increasing to 92 in the east. Each five-minute by five-minute quad is further subdivided into 25 one-minute by one-minute sections. Within the one-minute section, the location is pinpointed by specifying the distance from an adjacent pair of one-minute section boundaries to the well. The Carter coordinate is written by specifying a pair of footages from the one-minute section boundaries and the reference boundary (north, south, east, or west) for each, the one-minute section number, the five-minute quad letter, and the five-minute quad number. A Carter coordinate and topographic index map of Kentucky is available by request, contact the Public Information Center (Publication Sales).
A Carter coordinate location is defined only for the North American Datum of 1927 (NAD27). If you use the KGS Coordinate Conversion Tool to convert a NAD83 location to a Carter coordinate
the output will be NAD27 only.  https://www.uky.edu/KGS/emsweb/kyogfaq/kyogfaq9.html,,PPDM Members,,,,

The Dominion Land Survey (DLS; French: arpentage des terres fédérales, ATF) is the method used to divide most of Western Canada into one-square-mile (2.6 km2) sections for agricultural and other purposes. It is based on the layout of the Public Land Survey System used in the United States, but has several differences. The DLS is the dominant survey method in the Prairie provinces, and it is also used in British Columbia along the Railway Belt (near the main line of the Canadian Pacific Railway), and in the Peace River Block in the northeast of the province. (Although British Columbia entered Confederation with control over its own lands, unlike the Northwest Territories and the Prairie provinces, British Columbia transferred these lands to the federal Government as a condition of the building of the Canadian Pacific Railway. The federal government then surveyed these areas under the DLS.)[1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dominion_Land_Survey
and the results varied in some critical areas

such as the method for allocating road allowances.  For a full description read this document. http://sppi.ca/wp-content/uploads/2018/02/Understanding-Western-Canadas-Dominion-Land-Survey-System.pdf,,PPDM Members,,,,

The Canada Energy Regulator (CER) regulates oil and gas exploration and production work or activities on non-Accord federal lands across Canada under the Canada Oil and Gas Operations Act or the Northwest Territories Oil and Gas Operations Act as illustrated in the map below. Such work or activities often require a surveyed location description. The FPS uses a set of survey grids that have east and west boundaries every 10 minutes of latitude and a width of 15 minutes of longitude (south of 70 degrees North) that changes to 30 minutes (north of 70 degrees North). Each survey grid is further subdivided into sections and units.  https://www.cer-rec.gc.ca/nrth/pblctn/nmprcssfps-eng.html

A geodetic datum or geodetic system (also: geodetic reference datum or geodetic reference system) is a coordinate system, and a set of reference points, used for locating places on the Earth (or similar objects). An approximate definition of sea level is the datum WGS 84, an ellipsoid, whereas a more accurate definition is Earth Gravitational Model 2008 (EGM2008), using at least 2,159 spherical harmonics. Other datums are defined for other areas or at other times; ED50 was defined in 1950 over Europe and differs from WGS 84 by a few hundred meters depending on where in Europe you look. Mars has no oceans and so no sea level, but at least two martian datums have been used to locate places there.  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geodetic_datum

Datums are used in geodesy, navigation, and surveying by cartographers and satellite navigation systems to translate positions indicated on maps (paper or digital) to their real position on Earth. Each starts with an ellipsoid (stretched sphere), and then defines latitude, longitude and altitude coordinates. One or more locations on the Earth's surface are chosen as anchor "base-points".

The Texas Land Survey System is often measured in Spanish Customary Units. The most important of these is the vara, which, while ambiguous in the past, was legally established to be exactly 33 and 1/3 inches long in June of 1919.Gold, Kenneth G. (2009). Selected Texas Statutes and Boundary Decisions for Land Surveyors, Land Title Agents and Title Attorneys, Second Edition. p. 347.

Texas, along with the original thirteen states and several others in the Southwest which were originally deeded with Spanish land grants, does not use the Public Land Survey System [1] (also known as the Section Township Range and the Jeffersonian System. Land grants from the state of Texas to railroad companies were often patented in blocks and sections, and occasionally in units of square miles, officially considered sections.  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Texas_land_survey_system
At the time of perforating, the wellbore fluid pressure is equal to the formation pressure within expected tolerances.
This is the case if the operation intends to not induce flow in either direction.
Extreme overbalance perforating (EOP) is a microfracture-initiating process that is applied at the moment of initial perforating or as a surge process to existing perforations.

The technique uses stored gas energy in the tubing to break down the zone. Bottomhole pressure equivalents to 1.4 psi/ft and higher are applied instantaneously through the use of a nitrogen gas supercharge contained in the tubing
At the time of perforating, the wellbore fluid pressure is higher than the formation pressure.
This is the case if the operation intends to inject a completion fluid for reservoir treatment such as cleanup or fracturing.
At the time of perforating, the wellbore fluid pressure is lower than the formation pressure.
This is the case if the operation intends to allow the oil or gas to flow into the wellbore without prior treatment of the reservoir.

The property of rock samples that allows the passage of a gas (air, nitrogen, or helium) through the body in the presence of a differential pressure and usually should be corrected for non-Darcy effects.

Slippage-corrected gas permeability by either several measurements of gas permeability at different mean pressure and extrapolation to infinite pressure or measuring one single gas permeability and using a empirical correlation (e.g., Jones, 1987)

(Or Profile) Highly resolved measurements of permeability which is performed on slabbed cores especially in formations where conventional plug analysis cannot adequately capture the degree of heterogeneity
A physical condition in permeability measurement in which the flow rate of fluid passing through the core sample is steady (no change with time) for a constant applied ∆P at the ends of the sample
A physical condition in permeability measurement in which the flow rate of fluid passing through the core sample is not steady (changes with time)
Method designed for low permeability rock samples in an as-received state resulting in a relative permeability
A type of unsteady state gas permeability technique resulting in a maximum permeability to gas in crushed rock samples
Permeability measured in the vertical direction with respect to the wellbore.

Maximum measured permeability on that sample irrespective of orientation.
Permeability measured at  90 degrees or orthogonal to the Kmax direction
Brine fills the connected pore volume. Porosity is determined as brine volume divided by bulk volume.
The method is suitable for porosity related to primary depletion. Brine is better than fresh water because it does not usually cause clays to swell.
Helium fills the connected pore volume. Porosity is determined as helium volume divided by bulk volume.
Because the helium molecule is very small, additional isolated pores are included.

The pore volume is computed by measuring and summing oil, gas, and water volumes present in a freshly recovered core sample. Porosity is determined by dividing pore volume by bulk volume of the rock sample.
Historical or unusual method; details should be captured in remarks

A calculation of the time required for a seismic pulse to travel from the source to the datum plane and from the datum plane to the geophone. The velocity in the deeper surface of the earth, typically 1500 m/s or more.  Derived from SEG.org

Ceramic proppants are manufactured from sintered bauxite, kaolin, magnesium silicate, or blends of bauxite and kaolin. Compared to silica sand, ceramic proppant has higher strength and is more crush resistant.
Excellent crush resistance in a broad range of applications. It is designed for high performance under closure stresses of up to 14,000 psi.

The coating was made of a solid inorganic network having an amorphous three-dimensional structure that significantly increased the compressive strength of silica proppant.

North reference is not explicitly stated but is assumed as Grid north based on dates, historical trends, or other criteria.
North reference is not explicitly stated but is assumed as Magnetic north based on dates, historical trends, or other criteria.
North reference is not explicitly stated but is assumed as True north based on dates, historical trends, or other criteria.
The direction toward the north celestial pole, derived from astronomic observations.

This differs from True North slightly because astronomic instruments rely on gravity to define up (the vertical) whereas the earth's gravity field is seldom perfectly vertical. A Laplace Correction is applied to the astronomic north to get geodetic north (True North.) Astronomic north is seldom used in oil & gas operations but may persist in a legacy record.
Revised definition. Merged together with PPDM and OSDU original definitions

A raw reading of the north-seeking end of a needle or other magnetic component of a compass. This differs from magnetic north because of the influence of iron and other magnetic materials which disturb the Earth's magnetic field close to the compass instrument. There may be a correction applied to compass north to realize a magnetic north reading. This kind of north is encountered in older oil & gas data.
The direction of the north lines on a map projection.

In most projections only one north line points to true (geodetic) north; the central meridian in a UTM projection, for example. At any point on a grid there can be a convergence angle (defined) to relate grid north to true geodetic north. Grid north is not measured in the field; it must be calculated.
Revised definition. Merged together with PPDM and OSDU original definitions
North reference is not explicitly stated but can be confidently determined as Grid north based on other information data on the survey.
North reference is not explicitly stated but can be confidently determined as Magnetic north based on other information data on the survey.
North reference is not explicitly stated but can be confidently determined as True north based on other information data on the survey.
The direction to the Earth's magnetic north pole.

The direction in which a compass needle points. A declination correction is applied to calculate true north from magnetic north. Since the Earth's magnetic north pole is constantly in motion, the date and time an observation is made are critically important to apply the correct declination value.
Revised definition. Merged together with PPDM and OSDU original definitions

A direction in a local engineering coordinate reference system which is normally oriented more or less north. This is used in industrial facilities (like gas plants or offshore platforms) and for smaller areas like drilling pads. Distances and directions in this local system are easier to handle without need for a professional land surveyor because the need for accuracy is less and the distances involved are limited. In this case a surveyor might determine the location of a corner of the facility and the angle between true north and the apparent north of the facility.

The direction towards the true North Pole. Formally, it is the positive direction of that line parallel to the Earth's axis of rotation and perpendicularly to the left of an observer facing in the direction of the Earth's rotation.
True North is the common name of what is formally called geodetic north. It cannot be easily measured in the field. True north is normally computed from an imperfect measurement of north.
Revised definition. Merged together with PPDM and OSDU original definitions

Seismic segments are created in order to isolate portions of a line or survey that are acquired by different field crews, or with different acquisition parameters.
Segments are created based on the results of a quality analysis, with problematic sections identified for further investigation.

Segments are created so that the relevant portions of one or more seismic sets can be associated with a reservoir characterization study.  This provides a record of provenance for the study and is helpful in establishing levels of confidence.
Data from one or more segments may be merged mathematically or through rebinning data.  This establishes the provenance of the source data.
Data partnerships are often created based on geographic or time based boundaries.  Portions of seismic sets that are relevant to that partnership are identified.
Legal requirements, authorities or obligations may exist for these partnerships, so accurate identification is critical.
Seismic data may be sold in segments, particularly where purchased data must fall within particular geographic, time or acquisition parameters.

Seismic data is often leased from acquisition companies.  In this case specific rights and restrictions about what can and cannot be done with the data are in place, and must be associated with every relevant section of data.
Sections of seismic that contain interpolated or estimated data are identified to ensure that the resulting loss of trustworthiness can be described.
Sections of seismic data are inserted into interpretation software.  In this case, it is critical to know which part of which version of the data was used.

Seismic data is associated with specific obligations stemming from regulatory or contractual requirements.  Obligations can range from environmental (flowing hole control) to financial and information sharing.
Obligations range from environmental (flowing hole control) to financial and information sharing.
Sections of seismic data are inserted into processing software.  In this case, it is critical to know which part of which version of the data was used.
A section of a seismic set that has less than full acquisition fold coverage.
Seismic segments represent elements, which may be part of or an entire line, that are acquired under specific regulatory authorizations (permits) es or conditions.

A segment of seismic data that is reprocessed, or processed again following initial processing.  This is important where entitlements or obligations may specify whether this is allowed, or whether the results must be shared.

In cases where field acquisition is determined to be problematic (perhaps due to equipment problems or non-optimal design), a portion of seismic may be reacquired.  In this case, crews, authorizations, parameters and more may be different than the initial shoot.
The differences must be tracked while maintaining the relationship between the original and reshoot.

Brokered seismic data is sold in segments based on the requirements of the buyer.  A complete understanding of what has been sold (or leased) is important to track revenue and ensure that the seller's rights and expectations are met.
The reflecting point that is common to a subset of data.
Having the same midpoint between source and detector.

Sometimes erroneously called common-depth-point or common-reflection-point. The use of this term for common-midpoint to describe depth point is discouraged because the reflecting point is not in common if reflectors dip.
The location of a geophone or hydrophone (single or group) to measure the arrival of seismic waves.
The receiver location is normally at or near the surface but can also be in a wellbore.
The location of a device that generates energy as elastic waves.

Variable-depth streamer acquisition aims at the best possible signal-to-noise ratio at low frequencies by towing the streamer very deeply.
VDS uses a depth profile varying with offset in order not to limit the high-frequency bandwidth by notches as happens with conventional streamers.
A vibrator technique that produces independent records uncontaminated by simultaneous source interference.
Applicable to a range of offsets and depths that span all zones of interest.
This mode allows for sources beyond a certain separation to sweep simultaneously, with the distance set so that there is no overlap of reflected signal within the region of interest.
In flip-flop acquisition fleets move-up between source points while other fleets are sweeping, reducing the dead time between records.
The vibrator frequency varies linearly with time.

A hollow, retrievable, cylindrical bullet is shot into the borehole wall and retrieved with the rock sample inside.

A typical tool (gun) has multiples of approximately 30 bullets, each triggered remotely for a specific depth. The bullets are retrieved by wires connected to the gun. Percussion may damage the sample.
A diamond-tipped drill cuts a plug from the borehole wall. The drill and sample are retracted into the body of the tool.

The tool can obtain multiple samples in a single run. Rotary sidewall cores are more expensive but suitable for harder rock and for quantitative analysis because the cores are less damaged than by the percussion method.
A rotary sidewall core brought to surface at reservoir pressure.
The sample is depressurized under controlled conditions to study the reservoir fluids.
Biostratigraphic units (biozones) are bodies of strata that are defined or characterized on the basis of their contained fossils.

Biostratigraphic units exist only where the particular diagnostic feature or attribute on which they are based has been identified. Changes in the taxonomic interpretation may enlarge or reduce the body of strata included in a particular biostratigraphic unit. There may be several kinds of biostratigraphic units in the same interval, with gaps or overlaps of their vertical and horizontal ranges.
A chronostratigraphic unit is a body of rock, formed during a specified interval of geologic time.
Do not confuse rock units (Chronostratigraphic) and time units (Geochronologic.)
Geochronologic stratigraphy denotes the timing of events throughout all of Earth’s history that are interpreted from the rock record.
Geochronology denotes the time of rock events, including formation, erosion and deformation. Do not confuse rock units (chronostratigraphic) and time units (geochronologic.)
Lithostratigraphic units are bodies of rocks, bedded or unbedded, that are defined and characterized on the basis of their lithologic properties and their stratigraphic relations.
Lithostratigraphic units are the basic units of geologic mapping.
A body of rocks unified by similar magnetic characteristics which allow it to be differentiated from adjacent rock bodies.

The magnetic property most useful in stratigraphic work is the change in the direction of the natural remanent (residual from time of formation) magnetization of some rocks, caused by reversals in the polarity of the Earth’s magnetic field. Such reversals have taken place many times during geologic history.
A body of rocks bounded by seismic reflectors, each of which is interpreted as a surface of equal time across part or all of a sedimentary basin.
A seismic sequence is a body of rock whose lower and upper boundaries are reflectors interpreted as unconformities.
Unconformity-bounded units are bodies of rocks bounded above and below by significant unconformities.

The lithologic properties of these rocks, their fossil content, or their chronostratigraphic span are significant only to the extent that they serve to recognize the bounding unconformities. Unconformity-bounded units are objective stratigraphic units established and identified without regard for the genetic or causal interpretation of their bounding unconformities.
The direction of the remanent magnetic polarity recorded in the rocks of a stratigraphic interval.

The magnetic property most useful in stratigraphic work is the change in the direction of the natural remanent (residual from time of formation) magnetization of some rocks, caused by reversals in the polarity of the Earth’s magnetic field. Such reversals have taken place many times during geologic history.
Deprecated and superseded by another value
A grouping of two or more biozones with related biostratigraphic attributes.
A general term for any kind of biostratigraphic unit regardless of thickness or geographic extent.
Biozones vary greatly in thickness, geographic extent, and represented time span.
The body of strata representing the known stratigraphic and geographic range of a particular taxon or combination of two taxa of any rank.
The two principal types are taxon-range zones and concurrent-range zones.
The body of strata representing the known range of stratigraphic and geographic occurrence of specimens of a particular taxon.
It is the sum of the documented occurrences in all individual sections and localities from which the particular taxon has been identified.
The body of strata including the overlapping parts of the range zones of two specified taxa.
This type of zone may include taxa additional to those specified as characterizing elements of the zone, but only the two specified taxa are used to define the boundaries of the zone.
The body of fossiliferous strata between two specified biohorizons.
An interval zone is not itself necessarily the range zone of a taxon or concurrence of taxa. It is defined and identified only on the basis of its bounding biohorizons.
The body of strata containing specimens representing a specific segment of an evolutionary lineage.

A lineage zone may represent the entire range of a taxon within a lineage or only that part of the range of the taxon below the appearance of a descendant taxon. Lineage zones are the most reliable means of correlation of relative time by use of the biostratigraphic method.
The body of strata characterized by an assemblage of three or more fossil taxa that, taken together, distinguishes it in biostratigraphic character from adjacent strata.
The boundaries of an assemblage zone are drawn at biohorizons marking the limits of occurrence of the characteristic assemblage.
The body of strata in which the abundance of a particular taxon or specified group of taxa is significantly greater than in the adjacent parts of the section.
The boundaries are defined by the biohorizons across which there is notable change in the abundance of the taxon or taxa that characterize the zone.
The largest chronostratigraphic unit, greater than an erathem.
Three eonothems are generally recognized: Archean (oldest), Proterozoic and Phanerozoic. The geochronologic equivalent is an eon.
A major chronostratigraphic unit greater than a system.

A erathem has several systems. The names of erathems reflect major intervals of life on Earth: Paleozoic (old life), Mesozoic (intermediate life), and Cenozoic (recent life). The geochronologic equivalent is an era and uses the same names.
A unit of major rank in the chronostratigraphic hierarchy.
A system is composed of several consecutive series.
A chronostratigraphic unit ranking below a system.
A series consists of several consecutive subseries or (when subseries are not used) of several consecutive stages. The geochronologic equivalent is an epoch.
A chronostratigraphic unit ranking immediately above a stage.
A subseries has one or several consecutive stages. The term is used infrequently. The geochronologic equivalent is a subepoch.
The stage includes all rocks deposited between two chronostratigraphic horizons.

A stage is the lowest ranking chronostratigraphic unit recognized on a global scale. Stage boundaries (GSSPs) are defined by an international standard. The lower and upper boundaries of a stage represent moments in geologic time, and the time interval between them is the geochronologic age.
A substage is a chronostratigraphic subdivision of a stage.
A substage is restricted primarily to a regional scale. The geochronologic equivalent is a subage.
A chronostratigraphic unit of unspecified rank, representing rocks formed anywhere during the time span of some designated stratigraphic unit or geologic feature.
A chronozone is a formal unit but not part of the chronostratigraphic hierarchy. The corresponding geochronologic unit is the chron.
The interval of time that corresponds to the rocks, sediments and fossils in the type area for the chronostratigraphic eonothem of the same name.
The corresponding chronostratigraphic unit is the eonothem. Both unit types use the same name set, e.g. Phanerozoic Eon, Phanerozoic Eonothem.
The interval of time that corresponds to the rocks, sediments and fossils in the type area for the chronostratigraphic erathem of the same name.
The corresponding chronostratigraphic unit is the erathem. Both unit types use the same name set, e.g. Cenozoic Erathem, Cenozoic Era.
The interval of time that corresponds to the rocks, sediments and fossils in the type area for the chronostratigraphic system of the same name.
The corresponding chronostratigraphic unit is the system. Both unit types use the same name set, e.g. Devonian System, Devonian Period.
The interval of time that corresponds to the rocks, sediments and fossils in the type area for the chronostratigraphic series of the same name.
The corresponding chronostratigraphic unit is the series. Both unit types use the same name set, e.g. Miocene Epoch, Miocene Series.
The interval of time that corresponds to the rocks, sediments and fossils in the type area for the chronostratigraphic subseries of the same name.
The corresponding chronostratigraphic unit is the subseries. Both unit types use the same name set, e.g. Tortonian subepoch, Tortonian subseries.
The interval of time that corresponds to the rocks, sediments and fossils in the type area for the chronostratigraphic stage of the same name.
The corresponding chronostratigraphic unit is the stage. Both unit types use the same name, e.g. Albian Age, Albian Stage.
The interval of time that corresponds to the rocks, sediments and fossils in the type area for the chronostratigraphic substage of the same name.
The corresponding chronostratigraphic unit is the substage.
The interval of time that corresponds to the rocks, sediments and fossils in the type area for the chronostratigraphic chronozone of the same name.
A chron is a non-hierarchical unit. The corresponding chronostratigraphic unit is the chronozone. The magnetostratigraphic unit is the magnetic chron.
A Supergroup may be used for several associated groups with significant lithologic properties in common.
A succession of two or more contiguous or associated formations with significant and diagnostic lithologic properties in common.
Formations need not be aggregated into groups unless doing so simplifies stratigraphic classification in a region or interval. The component formations need not be everywhere the same.
An optional subdivision of a Group.
The primary formal unit of lithostratigraphic classification.
Formations are the only formal lithostratigraphic units into which the stratigraphic column everywhere should be divided completely on the basis of lithology.
The formal lithostratigraphic unit next in rank below a formation.
A member has lithologic properties distinguishing it from adjacent parts of the formation. Members are used only where a useful purpose is served.
The smallest formal unit in the lithostratigraphic hierarchy.
A bed is a layer lithologically distinguishable from other layers above and below. Customarily only distinctive beds (key beds, marker beds) are given proper names as formal units.
A discrete extrusive volcanic body distinguishable by rock properties.
The naming of flows as formal units should be limited to those that are distinctive and widespread.

A lithostratigraphic unit composed of diverse types of any class or classes or rocks (sedimentary, igneous, metamorphic) and characterized by irregularly mixed lithology or by highly complicated structural relations.
A lithostratigraphic unit recognized in preliminary studies and not fully described. Such names should be considered informal.
If a unit merits a formal name, it merits proper formal definition, description and publication.
A surface of lithostratigraphic change, commonly the boundary of a lithostratigraphic unit, or a lithologically distinctive very thin marker bed within a lithostratigraphic unit.
A surface is not a stratigraphic unit, but the lithohorizon term is sometimes used for a very thin marker bed.
A thicker interval of dominantly normal, reverse or mixed magnetozones.
This corresponds to the time interval of a magnetic superchron.
New NAME1, NAME4, definition and comment
The basic magnetostratigraphic unit is the magnetic zone or magnetozone, usually identified as a rock interval characterised by a specific (either normal or reverse) dominant magnetic polarity.
The interval of time corresponding to a particular magnetozone is the magnetic chron, which has a typical duration of about 100 thousand years to 10 million years.
New NAME1, NAME4, definition and comment
A thinner interval of opposing magnetic polarity within a magnetozone.
This corresponds to the time interval of a magnetic subchron.
New NAME1, NAME4, definition and comment
A body of rocks bounded above and below by specifically designated, significant discontinuities in the stratigraphic succession preferably of regional or interregional extent.

The diagnostic criteria used to establish and to identify an unconformity-bounded unit are its two designated bounding unconformities. Unconformity-bounded units may include any number of other kinds of stratigraphic units.
New NAME1, NAME4, definition and comment

The body of strata representing the known range of stratigraphic and geographic occurrence of specimens of a particular taxon. It is the sum of the documented occurrences in all individual sections and localities from which the particular taxon has been identified.
Changed NAME4, dropped parent, revised definition and added comment

The body of strata including the overlapping parts of the range zones of two specified taxa. This type of zone may include taxa additional to those specified as characterizing elements of the zone, but only the two specified taxa are used to define the boundaries of the zone.
Dropped HierarchyParent, revised NAME4, updated definition and comment
This is not an official value per Intl Comm on Stratigraphy.

An eonothem is a chronostratigraphic unit greater than an erathem. The geochronologic equivalent is an eon. Three eonothems are generally recognized, from older to younger, the Archean, Proterozoic and Phanerozoic eonothems. The combined first two are usually referred to as the Precambrian. The eons take the same name as their corresponding eonothems.
Dropped alias and parent, updated NAME4 and revised definition and comment
Dropped alias and parent, updated NAME4 and revised definition and comment

A system is a unit of major rank in the conventional chronostratigraphic hierarchy, above a series and below an erathem. The geochronologic equivalent of a system is a period. Occasionally, the terms subsystem and supersystem have been used.
Dropped alias and parent, updated NAME4 and revised definition and comment

The series is a chronostratigraphic unit ranking above a stage and below a system. The geochronologic equivalent of a series is an epoch. The terms superseries and subseries have been used only infrequently.
Dropped alias and parent, updated NAME4 and revised definition and comment

The stage has been called the basic working unit of chronostratigraphic because it is suited in scope and rank to the practical needs and purposes of intraregional chronostratigraphic classification. The stage includes all rocks formed during an age. A stage is normally the lowest ranking unit in the chronostratigraphic hierarchy that can be recognized on a global scale. It is a subdivision of a series.

The interval of time that corresponds to the rocks, sediments and fossils in the type area for the chronostratigraphic stage of the same name.
The corresponding chronostratigraphic unit is the stage. Both unit types use the same name, e.g. Albian Age, Albian Stage.

The interval of time that corresponds to the rocks, sediments and fossils in the type area for the chronostratigraphic series of the same name.
The corresponding chronostratigraphic unit is the series. Both unit types use the same name set, e.g. Miocene Epoch, Miocene Series.

The interval of time that corresponds to the rocks, sediments and fossils in the type area for the chronostratigraphic erathem of the same name.

The interval of time that corresponds to the rocks, sediments and fossils in the type area for the chronostratigraphic system of the same name.
The corresponding chronostratigraphic unit is the system. Both unit types use the same name set, e.g. Devonian System, Devonian Period.

The smallest formal unit in the hierarchy of sedimentary lithostratigraphic units, e.g. a single stratum lithologically distinguishable from other layers above and below. Customarily only distinctive beds (key beds, marker beds) particularly useful for stratigraphic purposes are given proper names and considered formal lithostratigraphic units.

Lithostratigraphic units recognized in preliminary studies and not fully described and characterized are sometimes given names. Such names should be considered informal and should not be included in published documents. If a unit merits a formal name it merits proper formal definition and description.
Revised NAME1, NAME4, revised definition and comment.
A surface of lithostratigraphic change, commonly the boundary of a lithostratigraphic unit, or a lithologically distinctive very thin marker bed within a lithostratigraphic unit.
Revised NAME1, NAME4, revised definition and comment.

The formal lithostratigraphic unit next in rank below a formation. It possesses lithologic properties distinguishing it from adjacent parts of the formation. No fixed standard is required for the extent and thickness of a member. A formation need not be divided into members unless a useful purpose is thus served. Some formations may be completely divided into members; others may have only certain parts designated as members. A member may extend from one formation to another. Specially shaped forms of members (or of formations) are lenses and tongues. A lens is a lens-shaped body of rock of different lithology than the unit that encloses it. A tongue is a projecting part of a lithostratigraphic unit extending out beyond its main body.
Revised NAME4 dropped hierarchy parent, updated definition and comment.

The term supergroup may be used for several associated groups or for associated groups and formations with significant lithologic properties in common. Exceptionally, a group may be divided into subgroups.
